Dot product

$u,v \in \mathbb{R}^n, u \cdot v \in \mathbb{R}$
$u \cdot v  = u^Tv$

$Au \cdot Av = (Au)^T \cdot (Av) = u^TA^TAv$

Magnitude/norm/length
$\lvert u \rvert = \sqrt{u \cdot u} = \sqrt\sum{u_i^2}$
${\lvert u \rvert}^2 = u \cdot u$

$u,v$ are orthogonal if $u \cdot v = 0$
If they are, then
    ${\lvert u + v \rvert}^2 = {\lvert u \rvert}^2 + {\lvert v \rvert}^2$

Cauchy-Schwartz Theorem:
    If $u,v \in \mathbb{R}^n$, then $\lvert u \cdot v \rvert \leq \lvert u \rvert \cdot \lvert v \rvert$

In 2D:
    $u \cdot v = \lvert u \rvert \lvert v \rvert \cdot \cos\theta$
    And $\frac{u \cdot v}{\lvert u \rvert \lvert v \rvert} \in [ -1,1 ]$

Triangle inequality
    $\lvert u + v \rvert \leq \lvert u \rvert + \lvert v \rvert$
    
$S$ is a subspace in $\mathbb{R}^n$    
    $S^{\perp} := \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^n \mid x \cdot u  = 0, \forall u \in S \}$

The vector orthogonal to all vectors in a plane is the normal vector
The space perpendicular to a vector is a plane with it as normal vector

To find $S^{\perp}$ given that $S = span(v_1 \dots v_k)$:
    $S^{\perp} = \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^n \mid x \cdot v_i = 0, i = 1 \dots k \}$
    You are finding every solution to a $k$ equation system
    Note that $x \cdot v_i = v_i^T x$, which we can stack into a column vector $V^Tx = 0$
    Then we are finding $\ker(V^T)$
$\dim(S) = rank(V)$
$\dim(S^{\perp}) = nullity(V^T)$
If $V \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times k}$ is a basis for $S$, then $\dim(S) = rank(V) = k$ and $\dim(S^{\perp}) = nullity(V^T) = n - rank(V^T) = n - k$

Later, $\mathbb{R}^n = S + S^{\perp}$

Orthogonal Set if all vectors $u,v \in S$ are orthogonal
An orthogonal basis is an orthogonal set that form a basis for $S$
But further, any orthogonal set is composed of linearly independent vectors, forming a basis

Given $x \in S$ and $\mathscr{B}$ is a basis for $S$, we seek ${[x]}_\mathscr{B}$
But note that $x = c_1v_1 \dots c_kv_k$ and $v_i \cdot x = c_i {\lvert v_i \rvert}^2$, so $c_i = \frac{v_i \cdot x}{{\lvert v_i \rvert}^2}$

Gram-Schmidt process (how to find such a basis)
   Given $u_{1 \dots k}$ as a basis for $S$, we are finding an orthogonal basis 
   We project e.g. $u_1$ onto $u_2$ for 2 vectors forming a plane in $\mathbb{R}^3$
   This projection is given by $\frac{u_2 \cdot u_1}{{\lvert u_1 \rvert}^2} \cdot u_1$
   So, $v_1 = u_1$
   $v_2 = u_2 - \frac{u_2 \cdot v_1}{{\lvert v_1 \rvert}^2} \cdot v_1$
   $v_3 = u_3 - c_1v_1 - c_2v_2 = \dots$
